list.item: April 2022, EAD updated by Abigail Bowen and Connor Johnson

did.unittitle: Lowell Thomas Papers: Objects

repository.corpname: Marist College Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: The Lowell Thomas Papers encompasses a wide range of materials documenting the life, family, and professional career of Lowell Thomas. These materials include correspondence, administrative and financial documents, manuscripts, printed materials, photographic materials, motion picture films, audio recordings, and memorabilia.
did.langmaterial: The language of the materials is predominately English. Other languages include: Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Hebrew, Hindi, Italian, Spanish and Swedish.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a wide range of memorabilia and realia, including portraits, photographic equipment, furniture, clothing, hats, and other items belonging to Lowell Thomas, Lowell Thomas, Jr., or Harry G. Thomas. Of particular interest is the collection of printing plates used to produce, among other materials, promotional posters for Thomas's travelogues. The series is divided into eight subseries, some divided further into sub subseries, all arranged by subject. A project to create digital images of these objects is on-going.

acqinfo.p: The Lowell Thomas Papers were donated to Marist College by the Thomas family in 2006.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lowell Jackson Thomas was born in Woodington, Ohio on 6 April 1892 to two school teachers, Harry G. Thomas and Harriet Wagner Thomas. The family did not remain in Darke County, Ohio for very long because Lowell's father wanted to become a doctor. Harry G. Thomas's pursuit of a medical degree led the family to Kirkman, Iowa where five-year-old Lowell was enrolled in school for the first time. Harry's studies soon led him to the University of Nebraska. Upon graduation, Harry G. Thomas followed his brother's suggestion to begin his medical practice in the twin mining boom towns of Cripple Creek and Victor, Colorado. It was here in the rugged American West that Lowell spent the better part of his childhood and young adult years.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection

userestrict.head: Notice of Copyright
userestrict.p: Individuals requesting reproductions expressly assume the responsibility for compliance with all pertinent provisions of the Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. ss101 et seq. Patrons further agree to indemnify and hold harmless the Marist College Archives and Special Collections and its staff in connection with any disputes arising from the Copyright Act, over the reproduction of material at the request of patrons. For more information please visit the following website: http://www.loc.gov/copyright/title17/.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Description of item, date, location of item in order of series, box number, folder number ], in the Lowell Thomas Object Collection, Archives and Special Collections, James A. Cannavino Library, Marist College.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: These records are organized into 8 series: 1) Family, with three subseries, 2) Clubs, 3) Equipment, 4) Sports, 5) Tibet, 6) World War I/Travelogues, 7) World War II, 8) Miscellany, with two subseries. Subseries 8.2 has seven subseries.

note.p: The Marist College Archives and Special Collections staff wishes to express their deep appreciation to all of the parties that helped the Lowell Thomas Project come to fruition.

did.unittitle: 1. Family

scopecontent.p: Series contains objects from Lowell Thomas, Lowell Thomas Jr., and Harry G. Thomas.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1.1: Lowell Thomas

Lowell Thomas’s “Open Road” style Stetson fedora hat in Silver Belly 3x fur felt. Sold by Norman Sims “Hatter”, Salt Lake City, Utah. Size, 7¼ inches. Lowell Thomas’s initials stamped in gold on the sweatband

Lowell Thomas’s red wine colored wool felt Egyptian fez hat. Circular/round hat with flat top and black thread tassel with straw interior. Interior dark green in color. Stamped on sweatband is a nighttime desert landscape with two pyramids, palm trees and obelisk

Lowell Thomas’s sun helmet (safari or desert sun hat). Very fine cotton twill hat of sturdy construction with asymmetrical, angled brim, flat crown that has a cross-the-hat top leather band and buckle, and pleated fabric band. Deep pink cotton interior with crossed web for air flow. Medium size
LC Smith Corona typewriter

Two glass bottles from Cripple Creek & Victor Company, one bearing “The Pioneer Bottling Works. Victor, Co.” trademark and the other “The Standard Bottling Mfg. Co. Cripple Creek Colo.” [items are located in Lowell Thomas Gallery]
One VIEW-MASTER viewing device
Stewart Warner radio made in Chicago, Illinois by the Stewart Warner Speed Corporation. Metal sides and hinged wooden top; contains five vacuum tubes. Measures approximately 8¼ x 9 x 20 ½ inches.
Portrait of Lowell Thomas by Joseph A. Maturo (signed Jos. A. Maturo). Measures 38 x 29 inches.
1968 desk calendar (used) torn off to Monday May, 13. Still in plastic faux wood finish calendar holder
Empty plastic faux wood finish desk calendar holder
Empty brown metal desk calendar holder
Empty black art deco desk calendar holder
Worn bound desk note pad and pencil (used), inscribed with the name “Lowell Thomas” in gold lettering on the cover

Large block of Lucite containing a large steel nut and note card. Note reads “Mr. Lowell Thomas: This is a nut off the right hand side recoil mechanism of one of Count Felix von Luckner’s guns. Removed from the wreck of the SEEADLER on the reef at the isle of Mopelia, French Oceania, on April 25th, 1956 by Ralph Varady, Sincerely, Ralph Varady, Honolulu, Sept. 26th 1958”. Measures 6 x 6 x 2 inches

Dark brown/black bifold wallet bearing the name “Lowell Thomas” in gold lettering. Wallet contains two business cards of differing sizes 2 x 3 and 1½ x 3 inches respectively. Typeface on cards reads “Mr. Lowell Thomas”

1965 desk calendar (used) torn off to Tuesday, January 5. Contained in distinctive green leather desk calendar holder with 24k gold inlay reading “Lowell Thomas” on cover flap. Small gold tag on bottom reads “A&M Leatherlines Inc., New York, N.Y., Genuine Leather, 24k tooled”

Desktop pen holder and clock in distinctive green and gold leather motif with gold typeface reading “Lowell Thomas” centered in front of the clock. Small gold tag on bottom reads “A&M Leatherlines Inc., New York, N.Y., Genuine Leather, 24k tooled” Measures 10 x 4½ inches
Small desktop lighter in distinctive green and gold leather motif. Small gold tag on bottom reads “A&M Leatherlines Inc., New York, N.Y., Genuine Leather, 24k tooled” Measures 2 x 3½ inches
Desktop ashtray in distinctive green and gold leather motif. Small gold tag on bottom reads “A&M Leatherlines Inc., New York, N.Y., Genuine Leather, 24k tooled” Measures 1½ x 8½ inches
A large metallic letter “T” measuring 9½ x 6½ inches
CBS NEWS lapel pin measuring 1½ x 2 inches
Lowell Thomas’s Distinguished Service Award, presented to him by the National Association of Broadcasting, Chicago, Illinois, April, 1968. Measures 11½ x 15 inches
Lowell Thomas’s 1981 Audio - Visual Media Educator Recognition Award, presented to him August 5, 1981 by the National Audio Visual Association. Measures 10 x 15 inches
Small red change purse containing eight assorted keys
Unidentified brass object measuring 4 x 1½ inches
Small circular tape measure, measuring 2 x ¼ inches
Small fold-out magnifying glass
Two small replacement vacuum tubes for a tape recorder, wrapped in paper
Small empty plastic container once containing “Tape Recorder Head Cleaning Fluid.” Measures 3½ x 2 inches
Reel to reel rewind setup produced by the Craig Movie Supply Company. In original box. Measures approximately 6 x 4½ x 3½ inches
Four Philadelphia Evening Bulletin delegate signs
Circular photo frame. Measures 6½ x 6½ inches
Lowell Thomas Inn dinnerware cup, black and yellow motif
Lowell Thomas Inn dinnerware saucer, black and yellow motif
Lowell Thomas Inn dinnerware bowl, black and yellow motif
Lowell Thomas Inn dinnerware dish, black and yellow motif
Lowell Thomas Inn dinnerware dinner dish, black and yellow motif
Large, worn, brown steamer trunk with the word “Beirut” hand painted on side. Trunk is empty and measures 31 x 17 x 13 inches
Recognition plaque given to Lowell Thomas on 6 May 1981 by the University of South Carolina to honor the establishment of a scholarship in broadcast journalism
Lowell Thomas Board Game from Parker Brothers
Gold framed embroidery textiles [Indian?][Tibetan?]. Measure 30 ½ x 28½ inches [items are located in Marist College Special Collections hanging storage area]
Reddish-orange silk scarf with an intricate design [Indian?][Tibetan?]
Decorative sash, purple with a pattern of shapes that are blue, gold, pink and orange in color. There is also an intricate design of colorful beads on one side [Indian?][Tibetan?]
Decorative bag with a complex design. The primary colors are red, burgundy, green, pink, yellow and blue. Tassels are affixed to the bag [Indian or Tibetan?]
Decorative bag, mainly burgundy in color. There is a design of shells and two tassels affixed to bag [Indian?][Tibetan?]
Decorative bag with a pattern in colors of green, burgundy, pink, and yellow [Indian?][Tibetan?]
Lowell Thomas’s Honorary Doctorate from Marist College with President Dennis J. Murray’s signature. Latin language. Measures 18 x 22 inches (including frame)
Subseries 1.2: Lowell Thomas, Jr.

Pair of khaki colored men’s shorts, Abercrombie & Fitch

Worn, dark brown leather briefcase, with a brass clasp and initials “L.T. jr.” on front

Copper potato chip award given to Lowell Thomas Jr. in 1954. Inscribed “Chip off the old block, From the National Potato Chip Institute, to Lowell Thomas Jr., 1954”. Includes marble stand. Measures approximately 4¾ x 4½ inches
Subseries 1.3: Harry G. Thomas
Wooden box containing stainless steel physician’s tools. Measuring approximately 12 x 6 x 2 inches
2. Clubs

scopecontent.p: Series contains objects from The Explorers Club

did.unittitle: Subseries 2.1: The Explorers Club
Bronze bust of Lowell Thomas, measuring 9 x 14¼ inches. American Sculptor Philip Kraczkowski was commissioned by The Explorers Club to sculpt the bust
The Explorers Club 75th Anniversary Award. Bronze medallion encased in Lucite reading “Lowell Thomas Award, The Explorers Club 1905, Lowell Thomas”
3. Equipment
Cine Kodak 16mm [millimeter] movie camera, manufactured by Eastman Kodak (Rochester, New York) from 1925-1931. Leather covered metal camera body. Measures 5 x 9 inches
DeVry Motion Picture Camera 7 x 9 inches manufactured by DeVry Corporation (Chicago, Illinois). Equipped with Kodak Anastigmat lens
Camerette 16, 35 [51 x 39 inches] standard reflex movie camera with lens. Manufactured in Éclair, Paris. With Éclair Tripod
Kodascope radio rewind universal splicer, measuring approximately 6½ x 29½ x 5½ inches
BUHL 8 (inch), 3.9 lens for carousel/ektagraphic slide projector, boxed
Black hard shell lantern slide carrying case. With silver clasp and key. Measures approximately 10½ x 8½ x 5½ inches
Leather camera case. Enclosed in the case is Kodak film. Measures 10¼ x 8 x 8 1/2 inches
Cine Kodak Model B movie camera case. Manufactured by the Eastman Kodak Company. Measures 10½ x 4½ x 7½ inches
Camera box which contains a Kinoptik lens. Box measures approximately 12 x 5 x 9¼ inches
RCA Radiola with the head set. Measures 8½ x 6½ x 5 inches
Motion picture camera equipment (6 pieces). Includes 2 Kinoptik lenses (Paris F 2S Focale, 150 mm, No. 24818, Kinoptik Paris, Odyssey)
Trans Twinister/Gates M1568 model. Measures 7½ x 6¼ inches
G. Nicks audio head set
Philco radio (wooden case). Model 37-60, Palt. 10226-A. Measures 20 x 16 x 10 inches
Bronze presentation plaque. Part of the radio “Star of Stars Contest” by readers of Radio Guide, 1936. Most popular news commentator. Measures 6 x 9 inches
Graflex Camera (folding box camera). Measures 6 x 6 x 7 inches
2 “Woodsman’s Pals” (machetes)
Estwing Chisel Point Rock Hammer. Measures about 12 inches

Realist 620 slide projector. Measures 12 x 7½ x 4½ inches
Bell & Howell Film Sound Projector. Measures 9 x 20 x 9 inches
2 wooden book blocks. Measure 7 x 6 x 2¼ inches
Needles from Speak O-Phone personal phonograph records
Equipment possibly related to the development of film. A wooden box contains a mirror as well as a light. Measures 13¼ x10½ x 3 inches
Black library card catalog cabinet with two drawers. Measures 12 x 12 x 4½ inches
Black library card catalog cabinet with two drawers. Measures 12 x 12 x 4½ inches
Wooden black lantern slide holder. The holder is open and contains two tan straps at either end. Measures 12½ x 4 x 4 inches
A green, metal film index card cabinet. Measures 16 x 6½ 5 inches
Kodachrome 35 millimeter slide box. Holds up to 100 slides. Measures 6 x 10 x 2½ inches
Kodak 35 millimeter slide carousel. Holds up to 140 slides. Measures approximately 10 x 10 x 2½ inches
Kodak 35 millimeter slide carousel. It can hold up to 140 slides. Measures approximately 10 x 10 x 2½ inches
Kodak 35 millimeter slide carousel. It can hold up to 80 slides. Measures approximately 10 x 10 x 2½ inches
One of several handmade wooden crates that housed Frank R. Roberson’s glass plate negatives. Measures 16 x 11 x 10 inches
Wooden crate used to house glass plate negatives. Measures 13¼ x 7½ x 8 inches
Brown, portable file cabinet used by Lowell Thomas, Jr. Measures 12½ 5½ x 12 inches
Brown phonograph record album box. Measures 12 x 4½ x 13 inches
Brown phonograph record album box. Measures 13 x 6½ x 13 inches
Memorex Mark III computer memory disk. United States patent number 3,474,073. Measures 1½ x 15 inches
4. Sports

Vintage practice hockey puck, unused and still in original box. Label on box reads “Alex Taylor Co. Inc., The House that Sport Built, 22 East 42nd St. New York, N.Y., No.P., Practice Puck”. Puck itself is stamped with company logo and address
Vintage Spalding Duro Seam Softball, unused and in original box and wrapping
5. Tibet
Handmade wool Tibetan hat with distinctive pointed ear flaps and asymmetrical design using colorful striped wool in gold, blue, silver and black and hand-embroidered flowers. Vibrant red interior
Tibetan copper urn with holder and top. Decoratively tooled exterior featuring brass appliqué. Measures 13½ x 16½ inches

Tibetan Long Horn, three-piece, telescoping extension stored in the closed position. Decorative metal clasp attached to wide end of horn with additional decorative metal work at the end of each extension and mouthpiece. The Rag-Dung is a ceremonial instrument that is played to accompany chanting.
A pair of well-worn wooden crutches used by Lowell Thomas after he broke his hip from a horseback fall on leaving Tibet
Tibetan handcrafted beaded bangle bracelet in geometric design. Glass beads of green, ochre, burgundy, dark blue and white on padded cloth
Loomed Tibetan cotton satchel in blue, pink and burgundy on off-white field. Pull-tie closure, containing a collection of exotic sea shells
A set of raw leather reins
Tibetan painted ceremonial mask depicting a fanged mythological creature. Measures approximately 12 x 13 x 2 inches
Tibetan painted ceremonial mask depicting a mythological creature. Measures approximately 7 x 7 x 2 inches
Carved circular wooden Tibetan bowl containing four small dice and twenty-two copper coins. Measures 4 x 1½ inches
Carved circular wooden Tibetan bowl containing twenty-six metallic pegs. Measures 4 x 1½ inches
Unidentified sewn circular leather disc measuring 7½ x 1 inches
Brass Tibetan candle stand, silver plated with etched and colored floral motif. Measures 7¾ x 8½ inches
Brass Tibetan candle stand, with etched silver and brass plating. Measures 7 x 7¼ inches
Conical shaped Tibetan hat made of palm leaves overlaid with fabric appliqué containing colorful felt flowers
Traditional Tibetan apron of striped woven material overlaid with gold, floral-patterned damask at upper corners. Woven ribbon tie. Backed with synthetic turquoise fabric in geometric pattern

Lowell Thomas’s personal circular/round multi-colored fabric hat with flat top. Has a woven appearance and black fabric interior. Gift of the Lamas of the Tibetan holy city of Lhasa during Lowell Thomas’s 1949 visit

Lowell Thomas’s personal circular hat with flat crown and brim in gold lacquer with Southeast Asian decorative motif. Crown has air holes surrounded by stylized Asian symbols. Padded cloth sweatband and red silk under chin ties

Lowell Thomas’s personal Tibetan appliqué hat with brim. Woven green silk head band and woven silk crown appliqué outlined in red. Navy blue string to hold hat in place. Red silk lined crown and lower brim. Golden rick rack trim at edge of brim and on hat band
Lowell Thomas’s personal hand sewn Tibetan style long robe in aged cream silk with mandarin collar and fuchsia pink partial lining

Four ecru silk napkins/hand towels with colorful hand embroidery depicting four Tibetan village scenes, two male and two female: farming crops, hunting game, weaving fabric and churning butter. Measures 17 x 9½ inches
Three identical, colorful, woven Tibetan textiles. Measures approximately 25 x 7 inches
Tibetan flag in traditional colors with rising sun motif from the late 1960s - 1970s
Collection of seven Tibetan ceremonial white silk scarves with frayed edges
Collection of four Tibetan ceremonial white scarves in assorted fabrics with frayed fringe edges
Lowell Thomas’s personal Tibetan ceremonial red silk scarf. Handwritten note by Lowell Thomas accompanies scarf: “Tibetan ceremonial scarves. Red scarves are usually given by Dalai Lama”
Tibetan ceremonial red silk scarf
Collection of seventeen handcrafted handheld fans, embroidered on one or both sides in colorful floral designs. The fabrics use an assortment of patterns, fabrics and shapes
Stone carving of praying Buddha. Measures 8½ x 12 inches
5 copper engraving plates. 2 measure 2½ x 1½ inches; 2 measure 1¾ x 1¾ inches; 1 measures 3 x 1½ inches; All have a height of ¾ of an inch
Seven pieces of Tibetan silver
Tibetan beaded necklace with pendant. Round and oblong beads inlaid with turquoise and silver
Tibetan bracelet. Floret shaped beads inlaid with turquoise and silver
Hand sewn Tibetan Thangka. Measures 27 x 25 inches

Tibetan flag given to Lowell Thomas by the fourteenth Dalai Lama when they met in Lhasa in 1949. The flag is both machine and hand stitched, and embroidered with colored thread. Measures 43½ x 45 inches [item stored in oversize tube]
6. World War I/Travelogues

World War I flannel-lined leather aviator’s helmet. Laces up the back, adjustable straps with buckles at the chin. Built-in ear flaps accommodate radio headset, and side snaps hold goggles in place. Goggles are hinged for a custom fit

World War I Pickelhaube, standard issue World War I German infantry black spiked helmet. Features fluted spike, cruciform spike base, squared visor rim, brass chin scales and red cockade around chinstrap fitting
World War I Italian “Adrian” M1916 helmet in grey-green painted metal. Helmet made in two pieces: the helmet shell and crest. Liner is Italian made leather with cloth head band in grey-green wool
Ceremonial knife/dagger, hand carved wooden handle with decorative white metal discs. U-shaped stitched leather sheath overlaid with traditional metalwork
Camel saddle of the Tuareg people, featuring tooled leather with brass decorative strips and incised tin detailing. Measuring approximately 31 x 14 x 37 inches

Turkish flag (white crescent moon and star on a red background). Very worn; frayed on lower left corner and damaged with numerous holes. Still rolled around a broken piece of the flag standard. Measures approximately 21½ x 36½ inches
French flag (tri-colored: red, white and blue). Measures approximately 34½ x 51½ inches
Plaster relief of T. E. Lawrence. Measures 7 x 11 x 1½ inches
Red eye-glass container measuring approximately 4½ x 2 inches. Company logo inside of case reads “Fort and Goodwin Jewelers, 2 North Broad St., Trenton, N.J.”
Mrs. Frances Ryan Thomas’s World War I Red Cross uniform pin; showing wear at the center. Measures ¾ x ¾ inches [the pin is inside item 1 (eye-glass container) where it was originally housed]
Mrs. Frances Ryan Thomas’s World War I metallic eagle Red Cross uniform pin. Measures 2½ x ¾ inches [the pin is inside item 1 (eye-glass container) where it was originally housed].
Mrs. Frances Ryan Thomas’s World War I metallic bar Red Cross uniform pin. Measures 1 x ¼ inches metallic bar. [the pin is inside item 1 (eye-glass container) where it was originally housed]
Lowell Thomas’s desert robe. Heavy deep brown wool with intricate golden embroidery on square collar. Tie-front with fine gold thread balls
7. World War II

Lowell Thomas’s World War II uniform jacket in army green wool twill from Luxemburg Civilian & Military Tailors, New York. “War Correspondent” patch appears over left pleated pocket with button-flap. Circular patch on shoulder reads, “U.S. War Correspondent”

Lowell Thomas’s World War II uniform slacks with custom label containing Lowell Thomas’s name, date of manufacture (3/22/45) and order number (#A7742). Taupe wool twill with side pockets and back inset pocket. Labels contain manufacturer’s information: “Luxemburg Civilian & Military Tailors, New York”

Lowell Thomas’s World War II uniform hat, made by Luxemburg Civilian & Military Tailors, 485 Madison Ave., NYC. Green woolen cap with leather brim and hat band with golden spread-winged eagle front-center. Gold fabric interior, size 7 3/8 inches. is signed by Lowell Thomas on the interior gold fabric; his name is printed in black ink on the leather sweat band: “L. Thomas, N.B.C., N.Y.”
8. Miscellany

scopecontent.p: Series contains minerals and printing plates

did.unittitle: Subseries 8.1: Minerals
A mud brick from the wall of an unearthed house at Mohenjo-Daro in the Upper Indus Valley
A piece of York Minster pillar
Rock with tile (four pieces) as well as a piece of detached sandstone off-white in color
Stone from Richmond Castle. Note: “No question as to how acquired, please?”
Quartz
2 reddish-pink stones
Two pieces of brownish-orange rock. One appears brick-like
Black striped rock
Several fragments of brown sandstone
Brown sandstone from Reunion Hall at Princeton
Black gneiss from the Firestone Library at Princeton
White marble from Whig Hall at Princeton
Broken piece of Greece pottery; reddish brown in color
Broken Buddha, grayish in color
Cylindrical shaped stonework marked with the letter Q
Bone shaped rock
Reddish-orange piece of brick. Accompanying note states: “St Peter’s Tomb F1”
Shiny grayish-white piece of rock

Stone from the Rock of Cashel. Accompanying note states: “This is a remarkable outcrop of limestone rising 200 feet. It was the seat of Munster kings from 370 until 1101 when King Murtagh O’Brien granted the Rock to the Church. St. Patrick visited Cashel in AD 450 and baptized the King Aengus. The buildings on the Rock include a tenth century round tower, Cormac’s Chapel, the Cathedral, the Hall of the Vicars Choral, and Saint Patrick’s Cross, as well as some modern tombs and enclosing walls”

A piece of the London Bridge. Accompanying note states: “This particular piece came from Sir John Rennie’s (1761-1821) famous five-arch bridge over the Thames River. The stone was removed during demolition. Included with this artifact is information outlining the London Bridge’s history”
Quartz
Several pieces of the window cusps of Happisburgh Church, Norfolk, England
A center piece of decorative flooring from Curium, Cyprus
Mosaic from Salamis in Cyprus
Quartz
Brick
Stone
Stone
Stone
Petrified wood
Lapis Lazuli. Accompanying note states it is from the tomb of Baber at Kabul
Fossil
Quartz left over from the construction of the Quaker Hill Country Club’s fire place
Red stone with bits of quartz left over from the construction of the Quaker Hill Country Club’s fireplace
Brownish-red and gray rock left over from the construction of the Quaker Hill Country Club’s fireplace
Small piece of purple fluorite
Gray rock
Four small stones. [items housed in a box labeled Genuine Powders from the Depot Pharmacy, Victor, Colorado]

Lowell Thomas on horseback. Used for With Allenby in Palestine and with Lawrence in Arabia travelogue posters, advertisements and promotional brochures. Measures 4 x 4¼ inches
Several camels in a row. Used for With Allenby in Palestine and with Lawrence in Arabia travelogue posters, advertisements and promotional brochures. Measures 1¼ x 4 inches
Lowell Thomas on camelback. Used for With Allenby in Palestine and with Lawrence in Arabia travelogue posters, advertisements and promotional brochures. Measures 3¼ x 3¾ inches

“Lowell Jackson Thomas Greatest Alaskan Travelogue.” The print contains snow covered mountain tops with a body of water and Lowell Thomas dressed in a bear suit standing next to a dog. Measures 7¾ x 5 and 2¼ inches
Three plates of Lowell Thomas probably from the early days of the travelogues. Measures 9¼ x 3¾ inches
Portrait of Lowell Thomas used for his travelogues. Measures 4½ x 3 inches
Print of a man in a suit wearing a hat. Used for Hindustan or Through Romantic India travelogue. Measures 3½ by 2 inches
A person wearing beads, holding a stick with a tea kettle on it. Possibly used for the Romantic India travelogue. Measures 3½ x 4½ inches

Man in Arab[?] garments tugging at a stubborn animal. Possibly used for With Allenby in Palestine and with Lawrence in Arabia travelogue posters, advertisements and promotional brochures. Measures 3½ x 1½ inches
Subseries 8.2.3: Tibet
Lhasa street scene. [4 copies] Measures 3 x 4½ inches
Corresponding caption plate for item 3 below. Measures 1¼ x 1¼ inches

Lowell Thomas standing next to unidentified man; caption: “There were many fascinating sights to be seen on the rocky road to Lhasa. So many, in fact, that the travelers don’t seem to have shaved every morning.” [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches

Caption: “Paying with Tibetan copper coins the coolies who helped us on one day’s journey. Their daily wage, less than fifty cents, is a good sum in the Orient.” [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches

Chief abbot, the Jokang in the distance. Caption: “The chief abbot of the Jokang poses against the background of its golden roof. In Lhasa the cathedral, politically important, stands beside the Foreign Office.” [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches

Split plate - one of the “Rice Heap” and the other of “Jewel Park.” The “Rice Heap” is the Drepung monastery. “The Jewel Park” was photographed with five high lamas who served as advisers to the Dalai Lama. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 5 inches
Split plate - one of a Tibetan abbey and the other of Lowell Thomas and Dorje Changwaba. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 5 inches
Interior of a Sera Temple. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
The home of Tsarong Shape. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½inches
Split plate - one of a Tibetan woman wearing a silk dress and hat and the other of a person painting a Buddha. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 5 inches
Lowell Thomas and the rescue team. Front row: Major A.K. Bose, nurse Emily Bateman, Roy Bisbee and Dr. Pal. [4 copies] Measures approximately 2 x 3 inches
Corresponding caption plate for item 1 above. Measures ¾ x 2 inches

A plate containing three images: One image is of shaggy, buffalo-like yaks on the plain of Phari; another is of Lowell Thomas in an improvised sedan with Dr. Pal on the left and Captain Patil at right; the third is of common folks at Lhasa. [4 copies] Measures approximately 5½ x 5 inches
A bazaar at Lhasa. [4 copies] Measures approximately are 3 x 4½ inches
Lhasa monastery with a monk spinning a prayer wheel. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
Lowell Thomas on the outskirts of Lhasa. In the distance is the Potala Palace. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
The Dalai Lama’s family. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
Monks serving as the Dalai Lama’s personal bodyguard. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
The aged abbots of Drepung Gompa. [4 copies] Measures approximately 3 x 4½ inches
A Tibetan army general. [4 copies] Measures approximately 2 x 3 inches

Woman and her daughter overlooking the Holy City. [4 copies] Measures approximately 2 x 3 inches
